Model crop growth.

Gro.Rd

Gro() models crop growth over time given species-specific parameters and climate data. It can be used to predict yield, determine regions that are suitable for growing a crop, and identify traits that have the most influence on yield.

Gro(initial_values, parameters, varying_parameters, modules, verbose = FALSE)

Arguments

initial_values

Parameter values that are known only at the start of the simulation period. These are recorded in the result. (a list of named numeric values)
parameters

Parameter values that are constant for the entire simulation period. These are not recorded in the result. (a list of named numeric values)
varying_parameters

Times at which a solution is desired and parameter values that are known a priori for the entire simulation period. These are not recorded in the result. (a data frame with at least the columns year, doy, and hour and optionally columns for parameters that are known a priori.)
modules

The model modules that should be run. Required modules are given in the details. (a list of named character values)
verbose

A logical variable indicating whether or not to print system startup information

Value

A data frame with the columns year, doy, and hour; and a column for each parameter in initial_values; and a row for each row in varying_parameters:

Details

An overview of model definitions

A model can be fully defined using two types of arguments: (1) the set of equations and (2) the parameters required by those equations. The set of all parameters in the model is commonly called the state.

State values can be known, a priori, for the entire simulation (a priori state), or known only at the start of the simulation period (calculated state).

Model implementation using Gro()

In Gro(), the sets of equations are passed via the modules argument, and the state is passed via the initial_values, parameters, and varying_parameters arguments.

The set of modules determines the parameters that must be defined in the state arguments. Each module has parameters it requires, which must be defined in exactly one of the state arguments

The state argument in which a parameter is defined determines whether a parameter is considered calculated state or a priori state. Parameters defined in initial_values are considered calculated state, whereas parameters defined in either parameters or varying_parameters are considered a priori state. The difference between parameters and varying_parameters is that values in parameters are considered constant for the simulation period, whereas values in varying_parameters may be different for each time point. Only calculated state variables are recorded in the output. A priori state variable values will overwrite any calculations of those values performed internally by the model.

State argument details

initial_values: Parameter values that are known only at the start of the simulation period. Parameter values are recorded in the output. If the model calculates the parameter value, it will change with time. If the model does not calculate the value, it will be constant with time, but it will still be recorded.

parameters: Parameter values that are known and constant for the entire simulation period. Values are not recorded in the output. If the model calculates the parameter value, the calculated value will be overwritten by the value in parameters.

varying_parameters: Parameter values that are known a priori at every time step in the entire simulation period. Values are not recorded in the output. If the model calculates the parameter value, the calculated value will be overwritten by the value in varying_parameters.

The data frame varying_parameters must contain at least the columns year, doy, and hour, specifying the times at which a solution is required. Times must be evenly spaced, and the difference in times must be given in the timestep parameter (units are hours).

Required module names and available modules

  • canopy_module_name

    • c3canopy, c4canopy

  • soil_module_name

    • one_layer_soil_profile, two_layer_soil_profile

  • growth_module_name

    • partitioning_growth

  • senescence_module_name

    • thermal_time_senescence, thermal_time_and_frost_senescence

Precompiled module and parameter sets

Sets of parameters and modules are provided for sorghum, miscanthus, and willow, and are named [crop]_initial_state, [crop]_parameters, and [crop]_modules, e.g., sorghum_initial_state.

Weather data are provided. These are typically for one year (January 1 to December 31) and should be subsetted to include only the period of growth. The function get_growing_season_climate() is provided as one means of subsetting climate data.

Examples

## Simulate sorghum growth
result = Gro(sorghum_initial_state, sorghum_parameters,
             get_growing_season_climate(weather05), sorghum_modules)

#> Error in as.data.frame(.Call(R_Gro_solver, initial_state, parameters,     varying_parameters, steady_state_module_names, derivative_module_names,     solver_type, solver_output_step_size, solver_adaptive_rel_error_tol,     solver_adaptive_abs_error_tol, solver_adaptive_max_steps,     verbose)): Caught exception in R_Gro_solver: "soil_type_selector" was given as a module name, but no module with that name could be found.
lattice::xyplot(Stem + Leaf + Root ~ TTc, data=result, type='l',
                auto=list(points=FALSE, lines=TRUE),
                ylab=expression('Biomass'~(Mg/ha)),
                xlab=expression('Thermal time'~(degree*C~day)))

#> Error in eval(substitute(groups), data, environment(x)): object 'result' not found

### The results can be combined with the data that were used to drive the model.
result = cbind(result, get_growing_season_climate(weather05))

#> Error in cbind(result, get_growing_season_climate(weather05)): object 'result' not found

## Change a subset of the parameters.
canopy_architecture = within(sorghum_parameters, {chil = 1.2; leafwidth = 0.05})
architechture_result = Gro(sorghum_initial_state, canopy_architecture,
                           get_growing_season_climate(weather05), sorghum_modules)

#> Error in as.data.frame(.Call(R_Gro_solver, initial_state, parameters,     varying_parameters, steady_state_module_names, derivative_module_names,     solver_type, solver_output_step_size, solver_adaptive_rel_error_tol,     solver_adaptive_abs_error_tol, solver_adaptive_max_steps,     verbose)): Caught exception in R_Gro_solver: "soil_type_selector" was given as a module name, but no module with that name could be found.
lattice::xyplot(Stem + Leaf + Root ~ TTc, data=architechture_result, type='l',
                auto=list(points=FALSE, lines=TRUE), ylab=expression('Biomass'~(Mg/ha)),
                xlab=expression('Thermal time'~(degree*C~day)))

#> Error in eval(substitute(groups), data, environment(x)): object 'architechture_result' not found
